Simple physical barriers (handwashing, facial masks, etc.) are being strongly encouraged because they are efficient, easily deployable, and inexpensive means to reduce viral spread.
2, 35, 36, 38− 42 Still, each of these measures presents specific problems, and it is questionable as to whether they are sufficient to reduce the reproduction number R below 1 without maintaining social distancing because their efficacy depends on the fraction of the population that fully comply with them. With the graphics in Figure 1 b–g, we illustrate everyday scenarios in which these measures may have limited efficiency, particularly in preventing the spread of airborne viruses in frequently used confined spaces ( e.g., toilets, elevators) and surface-deposited viruses in small-area surfaces such as handles, buttons, and handrails.
